subject: Re: [junit] testing WebStart apps
msgSnippet: ... Agreed. I just want people to expose themselves to both. They may not be aware of the choice. That and jWebUnit. -- J. B. Rainsberger, Diaspar Software
messageBody:
Mike Clark wrote:

>
> On Nov 17, 2003, at 3:13 PM, J. B. Rainsberger wrote:
>
> > Chappell, Simon P wrote:
> >> J.B.
> >>
> >>> (You mentioned HTTPUnit. If you're not using HTMLUnit, start.)
> >>
> >> As I started using HttpUnit this summer, I'm interested in what is it
> >> that you like about HTMLUnit better?
> >
> > The biggest difference is the style of writing tests. HTTPUnit centers
> > itself on the protocol, whereas HTMLUnit is more HTML friendly.
> >
> > In HTTPUnit, you create requests and send them.
> >
> > In HTMLUnit, you ask an HtmlPage for HtmlAnchors and click them; or for
> > HtmlTextInputs and set their values; or for HtmlSubmitInputs and click
> > them.
> >
> > I find it easier to understand what an HTMLUnit does, because more of
> > the HTML-ness of the user interaction is part of the tests.
> >
>
> That sounds like a personal choice.
>
> I find that some folks prefer HtmlUnit while others prefer HttpUnit.
> At the end of the day they both do basically the same thing.
> Therefore, my advice would be to pick the tool you're most productive
> using.

Agreed. I just want people to expose themselves to both. They may not be
aware of the choice. That and jWebUnit.
--
J. B. Rainsberger,
